inputAnchors.label: Chat Model
inputAnchors.name: model
inputAnchors.description: Only compatible with models that are capable of function calling: ChatOpenAI, ChatMistral, ChatAnthropic, ChatGoogleGenerativeAI, ChatVertexAI, GroqChat

inputAnchors.label: Agent Memory
inputAnchors.name: agentMemory
inputAnchors.description: Save the state of the agent

inputAnchors.label: State
inputAnchors.name: state
inputAnchors.description: State is an object that is updated by nodes in the graph, passing from one node to another. By default, state contains "messages" that got updated with each message sent and received.

inputAnchors.label: Input Moderation
inputAnchors.description: Detect text that could generate harmful output and prevent it from being sent to the language model
inputAnchors.name: inputModeration

data.label: LLM Node
data.name: seqLLMNode
data.description: Run Chat Model and return the output

inputParams.label: Human Prompt
inputParams.name: humanMessagePrompt
inputParams.description: This prompt will be added at the end of the messages as human message

inputParams.label: Messages History
inputParams.name: messageHistory
inputParams.description: Return a list of messages between System Prompt and Human Prompt. This is useful when you want to provide few shot examples

inputParams.label: Format Prompt Values
inputParams.name: promptValues
inputParams.description: Assign values to the prompt variables. You can also use $flow.state.<variable-name> to get the state value

inputParams.label: JSON Structured Output
inputParams.name: llmStructuredOutput
inputParams.description: Instruct the LLM to give output in a JSON structured schema

tabs.label: Update State (Table)
tabs.name: updateStateMemoryUI

hint.label: How to use
hint.value:
1. Key and value pair to be updated. For example: if you have the following State:
    | Key       | Operation     | Default Value     |
    |-----------|---------------|-------------------|
    | user      | Replace       |                   |

    You can update the "user" value with the following:
    | Key       | Value     |
    |-----------|-----------|
    | user      | john doe  |

2. If you want to use the agent's output as the value to update state, it is available as available as `$flow.output` with the following structure:
    ```json
    {
        "content": 'Hello! How can I assist you today?',
        "name": "",
        "additional_kwargs": {},
        "response_metadata": {},
        "tool_calls": [],
        "invalid_tool_calls": [],
        "usage_metadata": {}
    }
    ```

    For example, if the output `content` is the value you want to update the state with, you can do the following:
    | Key       | Value                     |
    |-----------|---------------------------|
    | user      | `$flow.output.content`  |

3. You can get default flow config, including the current "state":
    - `$flow.sessionId`
    - `$flow.chatId`
    - `$flow.chatflowId`
    - `$flow.input`
    - `$flow.state`

4. You can get custom variables: `$vars.<variable-name>`

tabs.description: This is only applicable when you have a custom State at the START node. After agent execution, you might want to update the State values

tabs.label: Update State (Code)
tabs.name: updateStateMemoryCode

hint.label: How to use
hint.value:
1. Return the key value JSON object. For example: if you have the following State:
    ```json
    {
        "user": null
    }
    ```

    You can update the "user" value by returning the following:
    ```js
    return {
        "user": "john doe"
    }
    ```

2. If you want to use the LLM Node's output as the value to update state, it is available as `$flow.output` with the following structure:
    ```json
    {
        "content": 'Hello! How can I assist you today?',
        "name": "",
        "additional_kwargs": {},
        "response_metadata": {},
        "tool_calls": [],
        "invalid_tool_calls": [],
        "usage_metadata": {}
    }
    ```

    For example, if the output `content` is the value you want to update the state with, you can return the following:
    ```js
    return {
        "user": $flow.output.content
    }
    ```

3. You can also get default flow config, including the current "state":
    - `$flow.sessionId`
    - `$flow.chatId`
    - `$flow.chatflowId`
    - `$flow.input`
    - `$flow.state`

4. You can get custom variables: `$vars.<variable-name>`

tabs.description: This is only applicable when you have a custom State at the START node. After agent execution, you might want to update the State values. Must return an object representing the state

data.label: State
data.name: seqState
data.description: A centralized state object, updated by nodes in the graph, passing from one node to another

tabs.label: Custom State (Table)
tabs.name: stateMemoryUI
tabs.description: Structure for state. By default, state contains "messages" that got updated with each message sent and received.

hint.label: How to use
hint.value:
Specify the Key, Operation Type, and Default Value for the state object. The Operation Type can be either "Replace" or "Append".

**Replace**
- Replace the existing value with the new value.
- If the new value is null, the existing value will be retained.

**Append**
- Append the new value to the existing value.
- Default value can be empty or an array. Ex: ["a", "b"]
- Final value is an array.

tabs.label: Custom State (Code)
tabs.name: stateMemoryCode
tabs.description: JSON object representing the state

outputAnchors.label: State
outputAnchors.description: A centralized state object, updated by nodes in the graph, passing from one node to another

inputParams.name: systemMessagePrompt

inputParams.description: This prompt will be added at the end of the messages as human message

inputParams.label: Messages History
inputParams.name: messageHistory
inputParams.description: Return a list of messages between System Prompt and Human Prompt. This is useful when you want to provide few shot examples

inputParams.label: Require Approval
inputParams.name: interrupt
inputParams.description: Require approval before executing tools. Will proceed when tools are not called

inputParams.label: Format Prompt Values

inputParams.description: Assign values to the prompt variables. You can also use $flow.state.<variable-name> to get the state value

inputParams.label: Approval Prompt
inputParams.name: approvalPrompt
inputParams.description: Prompt for approval. Only applicable if "Require Approval" is enabled
inputParams.default: You are about to execute tool: {tools}. Ask if user want to proceed

inputParams.label: Approve Button Text
inputParams.name: approveButtonText
inputParams.description: Text for approve button. Only applicable if "Require Approval" is enabled

inputParams.label: Reject Button Text
inputParams.name: rejectButtonText
inputParams.description: Text for reject button. Only applicable if "Require Approval" is enabled

tabs.label: Update State (Table)
tabs.name: updateStateMemoryUI

hint.label: How to use
hint.value:
1. Key and value pair to be updated. For example: if you have the following State:
    | Key       | Operation     | Default Value     |
    |-----------|---------------|-------------------|
    | user      | Replace       |                   |

    You can update the "user" value with the following:
    | Key       | Value     |
    |-----------|-----------|
    | user      | john doe  |

2. If you want to use the agent's output as the value to update state, it is available as available as `$flow.output` with the following structure:
    ```json
    {
        "output": "Hello! How can I assist you today?",
        "usedTools": [
            {
                "tool": "tool-name",
                "toolInput": "{foo: var}",
                "toolOutput": "This is the tool's output"
            }
        ],
        "sourceDocuments": [
            {
                "pageContent": "This is the page content",
                "metadata": "{foo: var}",
            }
        ],
    }
    ```

    For example, if the `toolOutput` is the value you want to update the state with, you can do the following:
    | Key       | Value                                     |
    |-----------|-------------------------------------------|
    | user      | `$flow.output.usedTools[0].toolOutput`  |

3. You can get default flow config, including the current "state":
    - `$flow.sessionId`
    - `$flow.chatId`
    - `$flow.chatflowId`
    - `$flow.input`
    - `$flow.state`

4. You can get custom variables: `$vars.<variable-name>`

inputs.systemMessagePrompt:
Use all previously collected website data:
- `text`
- `html`
- `images`
- `sitemap_content`
- `screenshot`
- `page_load_time`
- `meta_tags`
- `ssl`
- `mobile_friendly`
- `broken_links`
View the html of the site using the tool - Web Browser!
---

1. **Strictly evaluate** the following five categories:
   - **Menu (Presence & Organization)**
   - **Main Page (Structure)**
   - **Additional Pages (Structure & Connectivity)**
   - **Sitemap (Presence)**
   - **SEO Meta Tags & Schema Markup**

2. For each category, **output only** a numeric rating from **0.0 to 1.0** (in 0.1 increments).

3. **Answer Format**:
   - Provide each category and its rating on a new line, for example:
     ```
     Menu (Presence & Organization): 0.3
     Main Page (Structure): 0.5
     Additional Pages (Structure & Connectivity): 0.1
     Sitemap (Presence): 0.0
     SEO Meta Tags & Schema Markup: 0.4
     ```
   - **No additional explanations or commentary.**

4. Be **as strict as possible** with the final scores.

---

## Example Agent Outputs in Flowise

**Example 1**:
```
Menu (Presence & Organization): 0.3
Main Page (Structure): 0.5
Additional Pages (Structure & Connectivity): 0.1
Sitemap (Presence): 0.0
SEO Meta Tags & Schema Markup: 0.4
```

**Example 2**:
```
Menu (Presence & Organization): 0.2
Main Page (Structure): 0.4
Additional Pages (Structure & Connectivity): 0.3
Sitemap (Presence): 0.1
SEO Meta Tags & Schema Markup: 0.2
```

inputs.systemMessagePrompt:
Use all previously collected website data:
- `text`
- `html`
- `images`
- `sitemap_content`
- `screenshot`
- `page_load_time`
- `meta_tags`
- `ssl`
- `mobile_friendly`
- `broken_links`
View the html of the site using the tool - Web Browser!
---

1. **Strictly evaluate** the following three categories:
   - **Internal Links Destinations**  
   - **Anchor Links Destinations**  
   - **External Links Destinations**  

2. For each category, **output only** a numeric rating from **0.0 to 1.0** (in 0.1 increments).

3. **Answer Format**:
   - Provide each category and its rating on a new line, for example:
     ```
     Internal Links Destinations: 0.3
     Anchor Links Destinations: 0.5
     External Links Destinations: 0.1
     ```
   - **No additional explanations or commentary.**

4. Be **as strict as possible** with the final scores.

---

## Example Agent Outputs in Flowise

**Example 1**:
```
Internal Links Destinations: 0.3
Anchor Links Destinations: 0.5
External Links Destinations: 0.1
```

**Example 2**:
```
Internal Links Destinations: 0.0
Anchor Links Destinations: 0.2
External Links Destinations: 0.3
```

**Example 3**:
```
Internal Links Destinations: 0.7
Anchor Links Destinations: 0.6
External Links Destinations: 0.9
```

**Example 4**:
```
Internal Links Destinations: 0.5
Anchor Links Destinations: 0.5
External Links Destinations: 0.5
```

---

1. **Strictly evaluate** the following six categories:
   - **Business Phone**
   - **Business Locations**
   - **Social Media Links**
   - **Map Pin**
   - **Additional Links**
   - **Overall Contact Information Relevance & Accessibility**

2. For each category, **output only** a numeric rating from **0.0 to 1.0** (in 0.1 increments).

3. **Answer Format**:
   - Provide each category and its rating on a new line, for example:
     ```
     Business Phone: 0.3
     Business Locations: 0.5
     Social Media Links: 0.1
     Map Pin: 0.0
     Additional Links: 0.4
     Overall Contact Information Relevance & Accessibility: 0.7
     ```
   - **No additional explanations or commentary.**

4. Be **as strict as possible** with the final scores.

---

## Example Agent Outputs in Flowise

**Example 1**:
```
Business Phone: 0.2
Business Locations: 0.3
Social Media Links: 0.1
Map Pin: 0.0
Additional Links: 0.5
Overall Contact Information Relevance & Accessibility: 0.4
```

**Example 2**:
```
Business Phone: 0.0
Business Locations: 0.4
Social Media Links: 0.2

```

```

tabs.label: Update State (Table)
tabs.name: updateStateMemoryUI

hint.label: How to use
hint.value:
1. Key and value pair to be updated. For example: if you have the following State:
    | Key       | Operation     | Default Value     |
    |-----------|---------------|-------------------|
    | user      | Replace       |                   |

    You can update the "user" value with the following:
    | Key       | Value     |
    |-----------|-----------|
    | user      | john doe  |

2. If you want to use the agent's output as the value to update state, it is available as available as `$flow.output` with the following structure:
    ```json
    {
        "output": "Hello! How can I assist you today?",
        "usedTools": [
            {
                "tool": "tool-name",
                "toolInput": "{foo: var}",
                "toolOutput": "This is the tool's output"
            }
        ],
        "sourceDocuments": [
            {
                "pageContent": "This is the page content",
                "metadata": "{foo: var}",
            }
        ],
    }
    ```

    For example, if the `toolOutput` is the value you want to update the state with, you can do the following:
    | Key       | Value                                     |
    |-----------|-------------------------------------------|
    | user      | `$flow.output.usedTools[0].toolOutput`  |

3. You can get default flow config, including the current "state":
    - `$flow.sessionId`
    - `$flow.chatId`
    - `$flow.chatflowId`
    - `$flow.input`
    - `$flow.state`

4. You can get custom variables: `$vars.<variable-name>`

inputs.systemMessagePrompt:
Use all previously collected website data:
- `text`
- `html`
- `images`
- `sitemap_content`
- `screenshot`
- `page_load_time`
- `meta_tags`
- `ssl`
- `mobile_friendly`
- `broken_links`
View the html of the site using the tool - Web Browser!
---

1. **Strictly evaluate** the following three categories:
   - **Company Name (Presence & Consistency)**
   - **Company Logo (Quality & Placement)**
   - **Domain Name (Relevance & Professionalism)**

2. For each category, **output only** a numeric rating from **0.0 to 1.0** (in 0.1 increments).

3. **Answer Format**:
   - Provide each category and its rating on a new line, for example:
     ```
     Company Name (Presence & Consistency): 0.8
     Company Logo (Quality & Placement): 0.7
     Domain Name (Relevance & Professionalism): 0.9
     ```
   - **No additional explanations or commentary.**

4. Be **as strict as possible** with the final scores.

---

## Example Agent Outputs in Flowise

**Example 1**:
```
Company Name (Presence & Consistency): 0.5
Company Logo (Quality & Placement): 0.3
Domain Name (Relevance & Professionalism): 0.4
```

**Example 2**:
```
Company Name (Presence & Consistency): 0.2
Company Logo (Quality & Placement): 0.0
Domain Name (Relevance & Professionalism): 0.3
```

**Example 3**:
```
Company Name (Presence & Consistency): 0.7
Company Logo (Quality & Placement): 0.5
Domain Name (Relevance & Professionalism): 0.6
```

**Example 4**:
```
Company Name (Presence & Consistency): 0.3
Company Logo (Quality & Placement): 0.1
Domain Name (Relevance & Professionalism): 0.2
```
```

inputs.systemMessagePrompt:
This agent will collect **all final numeric evaluations** from the various agents and **calculate an average score** for each agent’s set of categories. No additional commentary or explanations should be provided.

---

## Steps

1. **Gather the final numeric scores** from each agent.  
   - Each agent has a set of categories (e.g., “Menu (Presence & Organization),” “Main Page (Structure),” etc.) and a numeric rating (`0.0` to `1.0` in `0.1` increments).

2. **Output the scores** exactly as each agent provided them:
   - Write the category name, followed by a colon, followed by the numeric rating (e.g., `Category Name: 0.4`).

3. **Compute the average** of each agent’s scores:
   - For each agent, after listing all ratings, **output a single line** with the text `Average Score: X`.
   - `X` is the arithmetic mean of that agent’s ratings, formatted as a number from `0.0` to `1.0` (with no extra commentary).

4. **No explanations or commentary** other than category lines and the average line.

---

## Example Output Format

Below are **examples** of how the Aggregator Agent might compile results from different agents. Each block shows sample ratings for one agent, followed by the calculated average.

### Example 1 (Agent 1 with 5 Categories)
```
Menu (Presence & Organization): 0.3
Main Page (Structure): 0.5
Additional Pages (Structure & Connectivity): 0.1
Sitemap (Presence): 0.0
SEO Meta Tags & Schema Markup: 0.4
Average Score: 0.26
```

### Example 2 (Agent 2 with 3 Categories)
```
Internal Links Destinations: 0.3
Anchor Links Destinations: 0.5
External Links Destinations: 0.1
Average Score: 0.3
```

### Example 3 (Agent 3 with 6 Categories)
```
Business Phone: 0.2
Business Locations: 0.3
Social Media Links: 0.1
Map Pin: 0.0
Additional Links: 0.5
Overall Contact Information Relevance & Accessibility: 0.4
Average Score: 0.25
```

### Example 4 (Agent 4 with 3 Categories)
```
Offerings Evaluation: 0.4
Pricing Evaluation: 0.3
Duration Evaluation: 0.2
Average Score: 0.3
```

### Example 5 (Agent 5 with 5 Categories)
```
Main Color Scheme: 0.2
Accent Colors: 0.4
Font Colors (Contrast & Legibility): 0.1
Link Colors (Visibility & Branding): 0.0
Icon Colors (Brand Consistency): 0.3
Average Score: 0.2
```

### Example 6 (Agent 6 with 4 Categories)
```
Main Font Family: 0.5
Main Font Style: 0.2
Additional Font Families: 0.0
Additional Font Styles: 0.4
Average Score: 0.28
```

### Example 7 (Agent 7 with 4 Categories)
```
Colors and Tone: 0.3
Content Relevance: 0.5
Context and Composition: 0.1
Artefacts and Quality: 0.0
Average Score: 0.23
```

### Example 8 (Agent 8 with 5 Categories)
```
Content Relevance to Site Section: 0.3
Content Relevance to Business Category: 0.5
Content Tone of Voice: 0.2
Content Length Appropriateness: 0.4
Content Contextual Alignment with Images: 0.1
Average Score: 0.3
```

---

**Note**:  
- For each agent, simply list their category ratings line by line.  
- Then provide a single `Average Score: X` line.  
- **No extra text** or explanation.  
- Keep the output minimal.  
- Round or format the average as needed (e.g., `0.26` or `0.3`).  
```

```

**Example 2**:
```
Main Font Family: 0.2
Main Font Style: 0.1
Additional Font Families: 0.3
Additional Font Styles: 0.5
```

**Example 3**:
```
Main Font Family: 0.0
Main Font Style: 0.7
Additional Font Families: 0.2
Additional Font Styles: 0.9
```
inputs.approvalPrompt: You are about to execute tool: {tools}. Ask if user want to proceed

inputParams.label: System Prompt
inputParams.name: systemMessagePrompt
inputParams.default: You are a research assistant who can search for up-to-date info using search engine.

inputParams.label: Human Prompt
inputParams.name: humanMessagePrompt
inputParams.description: This prompt will be added at the end of the messages as human message

inputParams.label: Messages History
inputParams.name: messageHistory
inputParams.description: Return a list of messages between System Prompt and Human Prompt. This is useful when you want to provide few shot examples

inputParams.label: Require Approval
inputParams.name: interrupt
inputParams.description: Require approval before executing tools. Will proceed when tools are not called

inputParams.label: Format Prompt Values
inputParams.name: promptValues
inputParams.description: Assign values to the prompt variables. You can also use $flow.state.<variable-name> to get the state value

inputParams.label: Approval Prompt
inputParams.name: approvalPrompt
inputParams.description: Prompt for approval. Only applicable if "Require Approval" is enabled
inputParams.default: You are about to execute tool: {tools}. Ask if user want to proceed

inputParams.label: Approve Button Text
inputParams.name: approveButtonText
inputParams.description: Text for approve button. Only applicable if "Require Approval" is enabled

inputParams.label: Reject Button Text
inputParams.name: rejectButtonText
inputParams.description: Text for reject button. Only applicable if "Require Approval" is enabled

tabs.label: Update State (Table)
tabs.name: updateStateMemoryUI

hint.label: How to use
hint.value:
1. Key and value pair to be updated. For example: if you have the following State:
    | Key       | Operation     | Default Value     |
    |-----------|---------------|-------------------|
    | user      | Replace       |                   |

    You can update the "user" value with the following:
    | Key       | Value     |
    |-----------|-----------|
    | user      | john doe  |

2. If you want to use the agent's output as the value to update state, it is available as available as `$flow.output` with the following structure:
    ```json
    {
        "output": "Hello! How can I assist you today?",
        "usedTools": [
            {
                "tool": "tool-name",
                "toolInput": "{foo: var}",
                "toolOutput": "This is the tool's output"
            }
        ],
        "sourceDocuments": [
            {
                "pageContent": "This is the page content",
                "metadata": "{foo: var}",
            }
        ],
    }
    ```

    For example, if the `toolOutput` is the value you want to update the state with, you can do the following:
    | Key       | Value                                     |
    |-----------|-------------------------------------------|
    | user      | `$flow.output.usedTools[0].toolOutput`  |

3. You can get default flow config, including the current "state":
    - `$flow.sessionId`
    - `$flow.chatId`
    - `$flow.chatflowId`
    - `$flow.input`
    - `$flow.state`

4. You can get custom variables: `$vars.<variable-name>`

tabs.description: This is only applicable when you have a custom State at the START node. After agent execution, you might want to update the State values

tabs.label: Update State (Code)
tabs.name: updateStateMemoryCode

hint.label: How to use

tabs.description: This is only applicable when you have a custom State at the START node. After agent execution, you might want to update the State values. Must return an object representing the state

inputAnchors.label: Start | Agent | Condition | LLM | Tool Node
inputAnchors.name: sequentialNode

inputAnchors.label: Chat Model
inputAnchors.name: model
inputAnchors.description: Overwrite model to be used for this agent

inputs.systemMessagePrompt:
Use all previously collected website data:
- `text`
- `html`
- `images`
- `sitemap_content`
- `screenshot`
- `page_load_time`
- `meta_tags`
- `ssl`
- `mobile_friendly`
- `broken_links`
View the site through the tool - Web Browser!
---

1. **Strictly evaluate** the following four categories (related to the images on the website):
   - **Colors and Tone**
   - **Content Relevance**
   - **Context and Composition**
   - **Artefacts and Quality**

2. For each category, **output only** a numeric rating from **0.0** to **1.0** (in **0.1** increments).

3. **Answer Format**:
   - Provide each category and its rating on a new line, for example:
     ```
     Colors and Tone: 0.3
     Content Relevance: 0.5
     Context and Composition: 0.1
     Artefacts and Quality: 0.0
     ```
   - **No additional explanations or commentary.**

4. Be **as strict as possible** with the final scores.

---

## Example Agent Outputs in Flowise

**Example 1**:
```
Colors and Tone: 0.2
Content Relevance: 0.1
Context and Composition: 0.0
Artefacts and Quality: 0.3
```

**Example 2**:
```
Colors and Tone: 0.5
Content Relevance: 0.7
Context and Composition: 0.4
Artefacts and Quality: 0.2
```

**Example 3**:
```
Colors and Tone: 0.9
Content Relevance: 0.8
Context and Composition: 0.7
Artefacts and Quality: 0.6
```

inputs.systemMessagePrompt:
Use all previously collected website data:
- `text`
- `html`
- `images`
- `sitemap_content`
- `screenshot`
- `page_load_time`
- `meta_tags`
- `ssl`
- `mobile_friendly`
- `broken_links`
View the site through the tool - Web Browser!
---

1. **Strictly evaluate** the following five categories:
   - **Content Relevance to Site Section**
   - **Content Relevance to Business Category**
   - **Content Tone of Voice**
   - **Content Length Appropriateness**
   - **Content Contextual Alignment with Images**

2. For each category, **output only** a numeric rating from **0.0 to 1.0** (in 0.1 increments).

3. **Answer Format**:
   - Provide each category and its rating on a new line, for example:
     ```
     Content Relevance to Site Section: 0.3
     Content Relevance to Business Category: 0.5
     Content Tone of Voice: 0.2
     Content Length Appropriateness: 0.4
     Content Contextual Alignment with Images: 0.1
     ```
   - **No additional explanations or commentary.**

4. Be **as strict as possible** with the final scores.

---

## Example Agent Outputs in Flowise

**Example 1**:
```
Content Relevance to Site Section: 0.3
Content Relevance to Business Category: 0.5
Content Tone of Voice: 0.2
Content Length Appropriateness: 0.4
Content Contextual Alignment with Images: 0.1
```

**Example 2**:
```
Content Relevance to Site Section: 0.0
Content Relevance to Business Category: 0.2
Content Tone of Voice: 0.3
Content Length Appropriateness: 0.1
Content Contextual Alignment with Images: 0.0
```

**Example 3**:
```
Content Relevance to Site Section: 0.4
Content Relevance to Business Category: 0.7
Content Tone of Voice: 0.6
Content Length Appropriateness: 0.5
Content Contextual Alignment with Images: 0.9
```
